abstracts.cdata!:
The Land Administration Program Project
            develops an integrated, and decentralized land
            administration system to provide accurate information on
            urban, and rural land parcels, and effective land
            administration. This system should increase land tenure
            security, facilitate land market transactions, develop
            national and municipal territorial plans, and develop
            management plans for protected areas, forests, and
            indigenous peoples lands. Taking into account the context of
            the country's Agrarian Reform Law, Environmental Law,
            Cultural Heritage Protection Law, Territorial Land Tenure
            Law, and international norms, this Indigenous Peoples Plan
            (IPP), seeks to ensure that indigenous and ethnic groups
            living within the project area, are informed, meaningfully
            consulted, and mobilized to participate, and share the
            economic benefits of the project. The participatory process
            with local communities has established three levels as
            grievance mechanisms towards conflict resolution - should it
            occur - on issues regarding land tenure and transactions,
            and municipal territorial plans: a) at the national level,
            the National Indigenous Roundtable shall conduct an open
            dialogue, by which indigenous and ethnic groups, landowners,
            and government officials as permanent members, and in the
            presence of project staff, shall conform to a broad
            resolution; b) the relevant Council for Departmental
            Development (one Council per each eighteen departments in
            the country) will act as the regulatory authority overseeing
            the appropriate enforcement of the Territorial Land Tenure
            Law, who shall arbitrate should conflict occur at the local
            level; and, c) local ethnic community-based organizations
            shall resolve conflicts at the communal levels.
